name: Example quests
intro: A small template collection of combinatory logic exercises. Feel free to use this file as a starting point for your own quest chapter.

content.name: I from SK
intro: It can actually be derived from S and K alone —
Find a term built only from S and K that behaves like I.
content.hint: Think about what S K K x reduces to.

content.name: NAND for K/KI
intro: Using the Church encoding, K represents true and KI represents false.
Implement nand: it should return K (true) for every pair of inputs
except when both are K (true), in which case it returns KI (false).
Apply the result to true and false witnesses to observe it.

content.name: Linear basis from I and your own combinator
intro: form a complete basis for linear combinators — those that use every argument
Surprisingly, B and C can be merged into a single combinator.
Your task is to declare such a combinator P (lambdas are allowed here),
and then prove the basis is complete by implementing B and T

input.name: P
input.note: Declare your own linear combinator (lambdas allowed, no built-ins).

input.name: B
input.note: Implement B a b c = a (b c) using P and I.

input.name: T
input.note: Implement T a b = b a using P and I.
